fields.value: Evolution of Reporting P Values in the Biomedical Literature, 1990-2015
From JAMA. 2016;315(11) Chavalarias, D., Wallach J. D., Ting Li A. H., Ioannidis J. P. A.

authorAffiliation.value: Departments of Health Research and Policy and Meta-Research Innovation Center at Stanford (METRICS), Stanford University, Stanford, California
Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics, Western University, London, Ontario, Canada
Departments of Medicine, Health Research and Policy, and Statistics, and Meta-Research Innovation Center at Stanford (METRICS), Stanford University, Stanford, California

dsDescriptionValue.value:
Original dataset from the paper :

Chavalarias, D., Wallach, J.D., Li, A.H.T., Ioannidis, J.P.A., 2016. Evolution of Reporting P Values in the Biomedical Literature, 1990-2015. JAMA 315, 1141. doi:10.1001/jama.2016.1952
This dataset contains 4,572,043 P values in 1,608,736 Pubmed abstracts and 3,438,299 P values in 385,393 PMC full-text articles extracted from the entire Pubmed 1990-2015 and PMC sample.

The dataset of the manual analysis of 1000 abstracts and 100 full texts are also included (named Pval_April_2016.tab).

publicationCitation.value: Chavalarias, D., Wallach, J.D., Li, A.H.T., Ioannidis, J.P.A., 2016. Evolution of Reporting P Values in the Biomedical Literature, 1990-2015. JAMA 315, 1141. doi:10.1001/jama.2016.1952

fields.value:
This dataset contains several sql tables:
  • medline_full_txt_list : the list of all PMC papers analysed with mention of presence of abstract (abs=1), P-values in full text (pv=1), P-value in abstract (pv_abs=1).
  • medline_full_txt_pv : list of PMC P-values extracted in the PMC sample
  • medline_pt : list of P-values extracted in Medline abstracts with PT tags.
The extracted P-values are stored into a database with the following context details:
  • The publication date of the papers associated to the abstract mentioning the P value
  • The sign mentioned in the expression : <, <=, <<, ≤ , =, >=, >, >>,≥ or 'less than', 'of <'
  • The format of the P-value notation used, distinguishing between the following formats:
    • plain : 0,012 or 0.012 or .012
    • percentage : 1,2%
    • 10exp - any form of power of ten: 1,2.10-2, 1,2 x10(-2), 1,2 x10.Exp-2, etc.
    • exp - any notation involving 'e', 'E', 'exp' or 'Exp', without mention of the number 10 : 1,2.exp-2, 1.2 x Exp(-2), etc.
    • .int – any notation that seems to have a typo, like p=00001.
  • The Medline subset and category from which the abstract belongs to. When there were no references to any subset, the abstract and associated P values were flagged with 'No',
  • The journal ID of the paper,
Mysql was used for 'flat' storage and not for its relational properties. Since a given PMID can have several flag or PT or SB associated, the column 'first' indicates for each P-value record the first record of that P-value (first=1) and the other records (first=2). Other values of 'first' column indicates the maximal and minimal P-values at the item level. For example :
  • "SELECT * FROM `medline_full_txt_pv` WHERE first=1 and DP=1998" will select all P-values from 1998 without duplicate (but if 0.05 appears several times in a PMID, it will have several rows).
  • "SELECT * FROM `medline_full_txt_pv` WHERE flag='Research Support' " will select all P-values from the 'Research Support' category without duplicate (but if 0.05 appears several times in a PMID, it will have several rows).
After import of the sql you should have
  • 1,985,670 rows for the table `medline_full_txt_list`
  • 12,436,631 rows for the table `medline_full_txt_pv`
  • 16,116,061 rows for the table `medline_pt`
  • 9,088,701 rows for the table `medline_pvalues`
CSV export of all P-values and related meta-data All P-values and related meta-data have been exported without redundancy (one P-value appears exactly once) in three CSV files:
  • List of all PMC items processed. CSV of 843,884 lines corresponding the export of SELECT PMID, PMCID, DP, abs, pv, pv_abs, in_medline_sample, JID, ref FROM `medline_full_txt_list` WHERE FIRST =1
  • List of all PMC P-values. CSV of 3,438,299 lines corresponding the export of SELECT PMID, JID, sign, value, DP, format, abs FROM `medline_full_txt_pv` WHERE FIRST =1
  • List of all Medline P-values. CSV of 4,572,043 lines corresponding the export of SELECT sign, value, format, DP, JID, PMID, in_pmc_sample FROM `medline_pt` WHERE FIRST =1


The manual analysis of 1000 abstracts and 100 full texts is also included (named Pval_April_2016.tab). It contains :
  • Sheet 2: Journal Info Information about the 1000 abstracts: Journal
  • Sheet 3: Extractions_1000 All extractions are based on the abstract only level information. This means that for articles that report data: reviewers felt that reporting of P values of effects in the full text could not be excluded This means that for study design: Decions were based on abstract only Animal or human clarifications: Health policy were generally considered human, "organs" are either human or animal depending on the type of study, genes could be human or animal. If the article was about a technique on humans then it is human. Methods: Lab methods, statistical methods, scientific methods, diverse method based papers
  • Sheet 4: Extractions_Data_796 This means that for articles that report data: reviewers felt that reporting of P values of effects in the full text could not be excluded
  • Sheet 5: Full Text Real Random sample of 100 full text articles with data. Field of study now based on full text.
